review.title: Hierarchical Decision Making In Electricity Grid Management
review.abstract: The power grid is a complex and vital system that necessitates careful reliability management. Managing the grid is a difficult problem with multiple time scales of decision making and stochastic behavior due to renewable energy generations, variable demand and unplanned outages. Solving this problem in the face of uncertainty requires a new methodology with tractable algorithms. In this work, we introduce a new model for hierarchical decision making in complex systems. We apply reinforcement learning (RL) methods to learn a proxy, i.e., a level of abstraction, for real-time power grid reliability. We devise an algorithm that alternates between slow time-scale policy improvement, and fast time-scale value function approximation. We compare our results to prevailing heuristics, and show the strength of our method.

sections.heading: 2.2. Related work
sections.text: Several papers in the literature on energy systems, operational research, and more recently machine learning offer approaches to solving sequential stochastic problems through dynamic programming, most of which focus on energy storage (Lai et al., 2010; Xi et al., 2014; Jiang et al., 2014; Scott & Powell, 2012), unit obligation (Padhy, 2004; Dalal & Mannor, 2015; Ernst et al., 2007), and tendering strategies for the energy market (Song & Wang, 2003; Urieli & Stone, 2014; Jiang & Powell, 2015). To our knowledge, no work has been done to evaluate reliability in electricity grids.

sections.heading: 3. Problem Formulation
sections.text: Here we present a formulation for the two sequential decision processes that take place the next day (DA) and in real time (RT) in the sense of a hierarchical model of two MDPs. DA decisions are made to maximize the reliability of the system the next day. However, reliability the next day can only be assessed in RT and depends on the decision of the system operator in RT. This results in a complex dependence between DA and RT actions and system reliability. Therefore, we formulate the problem using two layers of intertwined MDPs: an RT-MDP that describes the state of the system, reliability and decisions on an hourly basis, and a DA-MDP that describes the DA action to select a daily subset of active generators based on predictions for the coming day. In our terminology, the former serves as a substitute for judgement of decisions made in the latter, see Figure 2.

sections.heading: 3.2.4. REAL-TIME REWARD
sections.text: In order to calculate the reliability of the system, we use the industry standard criterion N − 1, which evaluates the system's ability to withstand all contingencies of a single device. To calculate the reliability of the system, it is examined on the basis of a test sequence (contingency list), each test being an attempt to extract a single line (contingency) and check whether the system maintains safe operation. Therefore, reliability is calculated for a particular state of the network and depends on the current topology (et) and the changes in topology due to possible new contingencies (WRT). sections.heading: 4. Interleaved Approximate Policy Improvement
sections.text: In this section, we present our algorithms, called Interleaved Approximate Policy Improvement (IAPI), presented in Alg. 1, for collectively learning the RT reliability function while searching for an optimal DA policy. We use the term interleaved since the policy improvement in an MDP, 2006) to improve DA policy. Our method scales to large systems, using simple models with carefully designed functions and designs to run on distributed computing methods. As the algorithm is massively parallelizable, the faster convergence will be available. Our goal is to find an optimal DA policy.

sections.heading: 5. Experiments
sections.text: In this section we show the results of the IAPI algorithm on the IEEE RTS-96 test system, which is considered the standard test case in the system literature (Wong et al., 1999); see Figure 4. This test case is an example of a power grid in a medium-sized country that normally includes 73 buses, 99 generators and 120 transmission lines. We are updating the test case to include 9 additional wind generators to better represent current power grids. We use daily demand and wind profiles as published in (Pandzic et al., 2015). As stated in Sec. 1, this is a complicated, high-dimensional system that cannot be solved by bruteforce methods. The state space of this system may have O (2120) line configurations, with O (D73 · G9r) demand values (D) and wind generation values (Gr) at any time, which are of stochastic nature.

sections.heading: 6. Discussion
sections.text: In this paper, we present a networked two-MDP model, inspired by the hierarchical decision problem of managing the reliability of the power grid. The presented IAPI algorithm alternates between improving the DA policy and learning the RT reliability value. The IEEE RTS-96 network in our experiments is a sufficiently large network to capture the computing complexities that arise in real networks. In this work, we focus on the power grid, but our model can be adapted to other important applications with a hierarchical decision structure at different time levels, where a high degree of reliability and sustainability is required. Examples of such applications are sewer systems, smart cities and traffic control. The rough model presented in this paper was jointly developed as a first step with several SOs. This work is the tip of the iceberg and many improvements can be considered.
